text: my my my uh way of understanding this
financial crisis is in terms of two
different observations one is that that
Risk Managers and investment bankers and
actually all kinds of investors took on
more risk than they expected so there
was a failure of risk management there
was a failure to recognize how much risk
there was in some of these Securities
that people bought but a second and
perhaps more important point is that
many of these same people were paid very
well to ignore the risks and so there
are incentives which
are uh which Dort our ability to to
measure risk that is many times
we're we're not risking our own money
we're risking somebody else's money or
maybe that there is someone who's going
to uh back stop our downside but we
still get the upside there a lot of ways
that investment banking models work that
these risks are not uh internalized by
the people that are taking them and so I
think that's uh something that
investment banks have worried about for
a long time and are continuing to worry
about but it's not an easy solution when
you have lots of people betting the
company's money how do you really
allocate those risks how do you make
sure that the people that take the risk
are are feeling the risks in an
appropriate kind of
fashion well I would agree with that uh
I don't agree I I agree with a lot of
the points in Ty's book but I don't
agree with many of his
conclusions it seems to me that he he
rightly points out that Risk Managers
miss a lot of the the
risks but the conclusion is that he
draws is that we should abandon risk
management whereas my conclusion is we
should improve it uh I don't see what
the alternative to risk management is if
if if it's just going getting rid of the
models and instead using smart people
who can figure it out what how do you
train them what do you teach them how do
you just put them in a cockpit and let
them stumble for 10 years of their life
and then after that they're good at it I
think our markets have gotten so
complicated that we need risk management
but we just need to make it better we
need to be able to understand better
where these risks are coming
from and I think
actually one of the coming back to one
of your previous points about sort of
investment strategies one of the things
I think we might come out of this uh
crisis and uh I think that nasum is sort
of an example of this as well is that we
might
invest a part of our
Assets in portfolios that we don't
expect to do well now but we would
expect them to do well if we have
another
crisis and this is a different way of
thinking about asset
allocation uh it's an old idea in
economics but it hasn't really been at
the center of much investment analysis
but I think now there's a lot of
interest in in these so-called hedge
portfolios which will outperform in a in
a crisis I mean we've always had gold
bugs but now we sort of realize that
treasury bills might be in the same
category and we have derivatives like
credit default swaps which are in this
category and we have derivatives like
volatilities that are actually an asset
class that we could invest in which are
now would outperform if we have another
financial crisis and so thinking about
these different assets uh and and I
should say this extends to lots of other
kinds of finan of uh long-term risks for
example if we think about the long-term
risk of of global warming you know some
of the portfolios we might consider
buying are portfolios which would do
especially well if we have uh a an
economy-wide I mean a
global uh climate change that that
impacts us uh very negatively there are
some companies will do well and so it
might make sense to hold some of those
in your portfolio
